accel_to_decel_enable.label: Enable accel_to_decel
accel_to_decel_enable.tooltip: Klipper's max_accel_to_decel will be adjusted automatically.

accel_to_decel_factor.label: accel_to_decel
accel_to_decel_factor.tooltip: Klipper's max_accel_to_decel will be adjusted to this %% of acceleration.

activate_air_filtration.label: Activate air filtration
activate_air_filtration.tooltip: Activate for better air filtration. G-code command: M106 P3 S(0-255)

activate_chamber_temp_control.label: Activate temperature control
activate_chamber_temp_control.tooltip:
Enable this option for automated chamber temperature control. This option activates the emitting of an M191 command before the "machine_start_gcode"
 which sets the chamber temperature and waits until it is reached. In addition, it emits an M141 command at the end of the print to turn off the chamber heater, if present.

This option relies on the firmware supporting the M191 and M141 commands either via macros or natively and is usually used when an active chamber heater is installed.

adaptive_bed_mesh_margin.label: Mesh margin
adaptive_bed_mesh_margin.tooltip: This option determines the additional distance by which the adaptive bed mesh area should be expanded in the XY directions.

adaptive_layer_height.label: Adaptive layer height
adaptive_layer_height.tooltip:
Enabling this option means the height of every layer except the first will be automatically calculated during slicing according to the slope of the model’s surface.
Note that this option only takes effect if no prime tower is generated in current plate.

adaptive_pressure_advance.label: Enable adaptive pressure advance (beta)
adaptive_pressure_advance.tooltip:
With increasing print speeds (and hence increasing volumetric flow through the nozzle) and increasing accelerations, it has been observed that the effective PA value typically decreases. This means that a single PA value is not always 100% optimal for all features and a compromise value is usually used that does not cause too much bulging on features with lower flow speed and accelerations while also not causing gaps on faster features.

This feature aims to address this limitation by modeling the response of your printer's extrusion system depending on the volumetric flow speed and acceleration it is printing at. Internally, it generates a fitted model that can extrapolate the needed pressure advance for any given volumetric flow speed and acceleration, which is then emitted to the printer depending on the current print conditions.

When enabled, the pressure advance value above is overridden. However, a reasonable default value above is strongly recommended to act as a fallback and for when tool changing.

adaptive_pressure_advance_bridges.label: Pressure advance for bridges
adaptive_pressure_advance_bridges.tooltip:
Pressure advance value for bridges. Set to 0 to disable.

A lower PA value when printing bridges helps reduce the appearance of slight under extrusion immediately after bridges. This is caused by the pressure drop in the nozzle when printing in the air and a lower PA helps counteract this.

adaptive_pressure_advance_model.label: Adaptive pressure advance measurements (beta)
adaptive_pressure_advance_model.tooltip:
Add sets of pressure advance (PA) values, the volumetric flow speeds and accelerations they were measured at, separated by a comma. One set of values per line. For example
0.04,3.96,3000
0.033,3.96,10000
0.029,7.91,3000
0.026,7.91,10000

How to calibrate:
1. Run the pressure advance test for at least 3 speeds per acceleration value. It is recommended that the test is run for at least the speed of the external perimeters, the speed of the internal perimeters and the fastest feature print speed in your profile (usually its the sparse or solid infill). Then run them for the same speeds for the slowest and fastest print accelerations, and no faster than the recommended maximum acceleration as given by the Klipper input shaper
2. Take note of the optimal PA value for each volumetric flow speed and acceleration. You can find the flow number by selecting flow from the color scheme drop down and move the horizontal slider over the PA pattern lines. The number should be visible at the bottom of the page. The ideal PA value should be decreasing the higher the volumetric flow is. If it is not, confirm that your extruder is functioning correctly. The slower and with less acceleration you print, the larger the range of acceptable PA values. If no difference is visible, use the PA value from the faster test
3. Enter the triplets of PA values, Flow and Accelerations in the text box here and save your filament profile

adaptive_pressure_advance_overhangs.label: Enable adaptive pressure advance for overhangs (beta)
adaptive_pressure_advance_overhangs.tooltip: Enable adaptive PA for overhangs as well as when flow changes within the same feature. This is an experimental option, as if the PA profile is not set accurately, it will cause uniformity issues on the external surfaces before and after overhangs.

additional_cooling_fan_speed.label: Fan speed
additional_cooling_fan_speed.tooltip:
Speed of auxiliary part cooling fan. Auxiliary fan will run at this speed during printing except the first several layers which is defined by no cooling layers.
Please enable auxiliary_fan in printer settings to use this feature. G-code command: M106 P2 S(0-255)

align_infill_direction_to_model.label: Align infill direction to model
align_infill_direction_to_model.tooltip: Aligns infill and surface fill directions to follow the model's orientation on the build plate. When enabled, fill directions rotate with the model to maintain optimal strength characteristics.

align_xy.label: Align XY
align_xy.tooltip: Align the model to the given point.

allow_multicolor_oneplate.label: Allow multiple colors on one plate
allow_multicolor_oneplate.tooltip: If enabled, Arrange will allow multiple colors on one plate.

allow_newer_file.label: Allow 3MF with newer version to be sliced
allow_newer_file.tooltip: Allow 3MF with newer version to be sliced.

allow_rotations.label: Allow rotation when arranging
allow_rotations.tooltip: If enabled, Arrange will allow rotation when placing objects.

alternate_extra_wall.label: Alternate extra wall
alternate_extra_wall.tooltip:
This setting adds an extra wall to every other layer. This way the infill gets wedged vertically between the walls, resulting in stronger prints.

When this option is enabled, the ensure vertical shell thickness option needs to be disabled.

Using lightning infill together with this option is not recommended as there is limited infill to anchor the extra perimeters to.

assemble.label: Assemble
assemble.tooltip: Arrange the supplied models in a plate and merge them in a single model in order to perform actions once.

autosave.label: Autosave
autosave.tooltip: Automatically export current configuration to the specified file.

auxiliary_fan.label: Auxiliary part cooling fan
auxiliary_fan.tooltip: Enable this option if machine has auxiliary part cooling fan. G-code command: M106 P2 S(0-255).

avoid_extrusion_cali_region.label: Avoid extrusion calibrate region when arranging
avoid_extrusion_cali_region.tooltip: If enabled, Arrange will avoid extrusion calibrate region when placing objects.

bbl_use_printhost.label: Use 3rd-party print host
bbl_use_printhost.tooltip: Allow controlling BambuLab's printer through 3rd party print hosts.

bed_exclude_area.label: Bed exclude area
bed_exclude_area.tooltip: Unprintable area in XY plane. For example, X1 Series printers use the front left corner to cut filament during filament change. The area is expressed as polygon by points in following format: "XxY, XxY, ..."

bed_mesh_max.label: Bed mesh max
bed_mesh_max.tooltip: This option sets the max point for the allowed bed mesh area. Due to the probe's XY offset, most printers are unable to probe the entire bed. To ensure the probe point does not go outside the bed area, the minimum and maximum points of the bed mesh should be set appropriately. OrcaSlicer ensures that adaptive_bed_mesh_min/adaptive_bed_mesh_max values do not exceed these min/max points. This information can usually be obtained from your printer manufacturer. The default setting is (99999, 99999), which means there are no limits, thus allowing probing across the entire bed.

bed_mesh_min.label: Bed mesh min
bed_mesh_min.tooltip: This option sets the min point for the allowed bed mesh area. Due to the probe's XY offset, most printers are unable to probe the entire bed. To ensure the probe point does not go outside the bed area, the minimum and maximum points of the bed mesh should be set appropriately. OrcaSlicer ensures that adaptive_bed_mesh_min/adaptive_bed_mesh_max values do not exceed these min/max points. This information can usually be obtained from your printer manufacturer. The default setting is (-99999, -99999), which means there are no limits, thus allowing probing across the entire bed.

bed_mesh_probe_distance.label: Probe point distance
bed_mesh_probe_distance.tooltip: This option sets the preferred distance between probe points (grid size) for the X and Y directions, with the default being 50mm for both X and Y.

bed_temperature_formula.label: Bed temperature type
bed_temperature_formula.tooltip: This option determines how the bed temperature is set during slicing: based on the temperature of the first filament or the highest temperature of the printed filaments.

before_layer_change_gcode.label: Before layer change G-code
before_layer_change_gcode.tooltip: This G-code is inserted at every layer change before the Z lift.

best_object_pos.label: Best object position
best_object_pos.tooltip: Best auto arranging position in range [0,1] w.r.t. bed shape.

bottom_shell_layers.label: Bottom shell layers
bottom_shell_layers.tooltip: This is the number of solid layers of bottom shell, including the bottom surface layer. When the thickness calculated by this value is thinner than bottom shell thickness, the bottom shell layers will be increased.

bottom_shell_thickness.label: Bottom shell thickness
bottom_shell_thickness.tooltip: The number of bottom solid layers is increased when slicing if the thickness calculated by bottom shell layers is thinner than this value. This can avoid having too thin shell when layer height is small. 0 means that this setting is disabled and thickness of bottom shell is absolutely determined by bottom shell layers.

bottom_solid_infill_flow_ratio.label: Bottom surface flow ratio
bottom_solid_infill_flow_ratio.tooltip:
This factor affects the amount of material for bottom solid infill.

The actual bottom solid infill flow used is calculated by multiplying this value with the filament flow ratio, and if set, the object's flow ratio.

bottom_surface_density.label: Bottom surface density
bottom_surface_density.tooltip:
Density of the bottom surface layer. Intended for aesthetic or functional purposes, not to fix issues such as over-extrusion.
WARNING: Lowering this value may negatively affect bed adhesion.

bottom_surface_pattern.label: Bottom surface pattern
bottom_surface_pattern.tooltip: Line pattern of bottom surface infill, not bridge infill.

bridge_acceleration.label: Bridge
bridge_acceleration.tooltip: Acceleration of bridges. If the value is expressed as a percentage (e.g. 50%), it will be calculated based on the outer wall acceleration.

bridge_angle.label: External bridge infill direction
bridge_angle.tooltip: Bridging angle override. If left to zero, the bridging angle will be calculated automatically. Otherwise the provided angle will be used for external bridges. Use 180° for zero angle.

bridge_density.label: External bridge density
bridge_density.tooltip:
Controls the density (spacing) of external bridge lines. Default is 100%.

Lower density external bridges can help improve reliability as there is more space for air to circulate around the extruded bridge, improving its cooling speed. Minimum is 10%.

Higher densities can produce smoother bridge surfaces, as overlapping lines provide additional support during printing. Maximum is 120%.
Note: Bridge density that is too high can cause warping or overextrusion.

bridge_flow.label: Bridge flow ratio
bridge_flow.tooltip:
Decrease this value slightly (for example 0.9) to reduce the amount of material for bridge, to improve sag.

The actual bridge flow used is calculated by multiplying this value with the filament flow ratio, and if set, the object's flow ratio.

bridge_no_support.label: Don't support bridges
bridge_no_support.tooltip: Don't support the whole bridge area which make support very large. Bridges can usually be printed directly without support if not very long.

bridge_speed.label: External
bridge_speed.tooltip:
Speed of the externally visible bridge extrusions.

In addition, if Slow down for curled perimeters is disabled or Classic overhang mode is enabled, it will be the print speed of overhang walls that are supported by less than 13%, whether they are part of a bridge or an overhang.

brim_ears.label: Brim ears
brim_ears.tooltip: Only draw brim over the sharp edges of the model.

brim_ears_detection_length.label: Brim ear detection radius
brim_ears_detection_length.tooltip:
The geometry will be decimated before detecting sharp angles. This parameter indicates the minimum length of the deviation for the decimation.
0 to deactivate.

brim_ears_max_angle.label: Brim ear max angle
brim_ears_max_angle.tooltip:
Maximum angle to let a brim ear appear.
If set to 0, no brim will be created.
If set to ~180, brim will be created on everything but straight sections.

brim_object_gap.label: Brim-object gap
brim_object_gap.tooltip: A gap between innermost brim line and object can make brim be removed more easily.

brim_type.label: Brim type
brim_type.tooltip: This controls the generation of the brim at outer and/or inner side of models. Auto means the brim width is analyzed and calculated automatically.

brim_use_efc_outline.label: Brim follows compensated outline
brim_use_efc_outline.tooltip:
When enabled, the brim is aligned with the first-layer perimeter geometry after Elephant Foot Compensation is applied.
This option is intended for cases where Elephant Foot Compensation significantly alters the first-layer footprint.

If your current setup already works well, enabling it may be unnecessary and can cause the brim to fuse with upper layers.

brim_width.label: Brim width
brim_width.tooltip: Distance from model to the outermost brim line.

center.label: Center
center.tooltip: Center the print around the given center.

chamber_temperature.label: Chamber temperature
chamber_temperature.tooltip:
For high-temperature materials like ABS, ASA, PC, and PA, a higher chamber temperature can help suppress or reduce warping and potentially lead to higher interlayer bonding strength. However, at the same time, a higher chamber temperature will reduce the efficiency of air filtration for ABS and ASA.

For PLA, PETG, TPU, PVA, and other low-temperature materials, this option should be disabled (set to 0) as the chamber temperature should be low to avoid extruder clogging caused by material softening at the heat break.

If enabled, this parameter also sets a G-code variable named chamber_temperature, which can be used to pass the desired chamber temperature to your print start macro, or a heat soak macro like this: PRINT_START (other variables) CHAMBER_TEMP=[chamber_temperature]. This may be useful if your printer does not support M141/M191 commands, or if you desire to handle heat soaking in the print start macro if no active chamber heater is installed.

change_extrusion_role_gcode.label: Change extrusion role G-code
change_extrusion_role_gcode.tooltip: This G-code is inserted when the extrusion role is changed.

change_filament_gcode.label: Change filament G-code
change_filament_gcode.tooltip: This G-code is inserted when filament is changed, including T commands to trigger tool change.

clone_objects.label: Clone Objects
clone_objects.tooltip: Clone objects in the load list.

close_fan_the_first_x_layers.label: No cooling for the first
close_fan_the_first_x_layers.tooltip: Turn off all cooling fans for the first few layers. This can be used to improve build plate adhesion.

compatible_printers_condition.label: Condition
compatible_printers_condition.tooltip: A boolean expression using the configuration values of an active printer profile. If this expression evaluates to true, this profile is considered compatible with the active printer profile.

compatible_prints_condition.label: Condition
compatible_prints_condition.tooltip: A boolean expression using the configuration values of an active print profile. If this expression evaluates to true, this profile is considered compatible with the active print profile.

complete_print_exhaust_fan_speed.label: Fan speed
complete_print_exhaust_fan_speed.tooltip: Speed of exhaust fan after printing completes.

config_compatibility.label: Forward-compatibility rule when loading configurations from config files and project files (3MF, AMF).
config_compatibility.tooltip: This version of OrcaSlicer may not understand configurations produced by the newest OrcaSlicer versions. For example, newer OrcaSlicer may extend the list of supported firmware flavors. One may decide to bail out or to substitute an unknown value with a default silently or verbosely.

cool_plate_temp.label: Other layers
cool_plate_temp.tooltip: Bed temperature for layers except the initial one. A value of 0 means the filament does not support printing on the Cool Plate.

cool_plate_temp_initial_layer.label: Initial layer
cool_plate_temp_initial_layer.tooltip: Bed temperature of the initial layer. A value of 0 means the filament does not support printing on the Cool Plate.

cooling_tube_length.label: Cooling tube length
cooling_tube_length.tooltip: Length of the cooling tube to limit space for cooling moves inside it.

cooling_tube_retraction.label: Cooling tube position
cooling_tube_retraction.tooltip: Distance of the center-point of the cooling tube from the extruder tip.

counterbore_hole_bridging.label: Bridge counterbore holes
counterbore_hole_bridging.tooltip:
This option creates bridges for counterbore holes, allowing them to be printed without support. Available modes include:
1. None: No bridge is created
2. Partially Bridged: Only a part of the unsupported area will be bridged
3. Sacrificial Layer: A full sacrificial bridge layer is created

curr_bed_type.label: Bed type
curr_bed_type.tooltip: Bed types supported by the printer.

current_extruder.label: Current extruder
current_extruder.tooltip: Zero-based index of currently used extruder.

current_object_idx.label: Current object index
current_object_idx.tooltip: Specific for sequential printing. Zero-based index of currently printed object.

cut.label: Cut
cut.tooltip: Cut model at the given Z.

cut_grid.label: Cut
cut_grid.tooltip: Cut model in the XY plane into tiles of the specified max size.

cut_x.label: Cut
cut_x.tooltip: Cut model at the given X.

cut_y.label: Cut
cut_y.tooltip: Cut model at the given Y.

datadir.label: Data directory
datadir.tooltip: Load and store settings at the given directory. This is useful for maintaining different profiles or including configurations from a network storage.

default_acceleration.label: Normal printing
default_acceleration.tooltip: The default acceleration of both normal printing and travel except initial layer.

default_bed_type.label: Default bed type
default_bed_type.tooltip: Default bed type for the printer (supports both numeric and string format).

default_filament_colour.label: Default color
default_filament_colour.tooltip:
Default filament color.
Right click to reset value to system default.

default_filament_profile.label: Default filament profile
default_filament_profile.tooltip: Default filament profile when switching to this machine profile.

default_junction_deviation.label: Junction Deviation
default_junction_deviation.tooltip: Marlin Firmware Junction Deviation (replaces the traditional XY Jerk setting).

default_print_profile.label: Default process profile
default_print_profile.tooltip: Default process profile when switching to this machine profile.

deretraction_speed.label: De-retraction Speed
deretraction_speed.tooltip: Speed for reloading filament into the nozzle. Zero means same speed of retraction.

detect_narrow_internal_solid_infill.label: Detect narrow internal solid infill
detect_narrow_internal_solid_infill.tooltip: This option will auto-detect narrow internal solid infill areas. If enabled, the concentric pattern will be used for the area to speed up printing. Otherwise, the rectilinear pattern will be used by default.

detect_overhang_wall.label: Detect overhang wall
detect_overhang_wall.tooltip: Detect the overhang percentage relative to line width and use different speed to print. For 100%% overhang, bridge speed is used.

detect_thin_wall.label: Detect thin wall
detect_thin_wall.tooltip: Detect thin wall which can't contain two line width. And use single line to print. Maybe printed not very well, because it's not closed loop.

disable_m73.label: Disable set remaining print time
disable_m73.tooltip: Disable generating of the M73: Set remaining print time in the final G-code.

dont_filter_internal_bridges.label: Filter out small internal bridges
dont_filter_internal_bridges.tooltip:
This option can help reduce pillowing on top surfaces in heavily slanted or curved models.
By default, small internal bridges are filtered out and the internal solid infill is printed directly over the sparse infill. This works well in most cases, speeding up printing without too much compromise on top surface quality.
However, in heavily slanted or curved models, especially where too low a sparse infill density is used, this may result in curling of the unsupported solid infill, causing pillowing.
Enabling limited filtering or no filtering will print internal bridge layer over slightly unsupported internal solid infill. The options below control the sensitivity of the filtering, i.e. they control where internal bridges are created:
1. Filter - enables this option. This is the default behavior and works well in most cases
2. Limited filtering - creates internal bridges on heavily slanted surfaces while avoiding unnecessary bridges. This works well for most difficult models
3. No filtering - creates internal bridges on every potential internal overhang. This option is useful for heavily slanted top surface models; however, in most cases, it creates too many unnecessary bridges

dont_slow_down_outer_wall.label: Don't slow down outer walls
dont_slow_down_outer_wall.tooltip:
If enabled, this setting will ensure external perimeters are not slowed down to meet the minimum layer time. This is particularly helpful in the below scenarios:
1. To avoid changes in shine when printing glossy filaments
2. To avoid changes in external wall speed which may create slight wall artifacts that appear like Z banding
3. To avoid printing at speeds which cause VFAs (fine artifacts) on the external walls

downward_check.label: Downward machines check
downward_check.tooltip: If enabled, check whether current machine downward compatible with the machines in the list.

downward_settings.label: downward machines settings
downward_settings.tooltip: The machine settings list needs to do downward checking.

draft_shield.label: Draft shield
draft_shield.tooltip:
A draft shield is useful to protect an ABS or ASA print from warping and detaching from print bed due to wind draft. It is usually needed only with open frame printers, i.e. without an enclosure.

Enabled = skirt is as tall as the highest printed object. Otherwise 'Skirt height' is used.
Note: With the draft shield active, the skirt will be printed at skirt distance from the object. Therefore, if brims are active it may intersect with them. To avoid this, increase the skirt distance value.

duplicate_grid.label: Duplicate by grid
duplicate_grid.tooltip: Multiply copies by creating a grid.

during_print_exhaust_fan_speed.label: Fan speed
during_print_exhaust_fan_speed.tooltip: Speed of exhaust fan during printing. This speed will override the speed in filament custom G-code.

e_position.label: Absolute E position
e_position.tooltip: Current position of the extruder axis. Only used with absolute extruder addressing.

e_restart_extra.label: Extra de-retraction
e_restart_extra.tooltip: Currently planned extra extruder priming after de-retraction.

e_retracted.label: Retraction
e_retracted.tooltip: Retraction state at the beginning of the custom G-code block. If the custom G-code moves the extruder axis, it should write to this variable so OrcaSlicer de-retracts correctly when it gets control back.

elefant_foot_compensation.label: Elephant foot compensation
elefant_foot_compensation.tooltip: Shrinks the initial layer on build plate to compensate for elephant foot effect.

elefant_foot_compensation_layers.label: Elephant foot compensation layers
elefant_foot_compensation_layers.tooltip: The number of layers on which the elephant foot compensation will be active. The first layer will be shrunk by the elephant foot compensation value, then the next layers will be linearly shrunk less, up to the layer indicated by this value.

emit_machine_limits_to_gcode.label: Emit limits to G-code
emit_machine_limits_to_gcode.tooltip:
If enabled, the machine limits will be emitted to G-code file.
This option will be ignored if the G-code flavor is set to Klipper.

enable_arc_fitting.label: Arc fitting
enable_arc_fitting.tooltip:
Enable this to get a G-code file which has G2 and G3 moves. The fitting tolerance is same as the resolution.

Note: For Klipper machines, this option is recommended to be disabled. Klipper does not benefit from arc commands as these are split again into line segments by the firmware. This results in a reduction in surface quality as line segments are converted to arcs by the slicer and then back to line segments by the firmware.

enable_extra_bridge_layer.label: Extra bridge layers (beta)
enable_extra_bridge_layer.tooltip:
This option enables the generation of an extra bridge layer over internal and/or external bridges.

Extra bridge layers help improve bridge appearance and reliability, as the solid infill is better supported. This is especially useful in fast printers, where the bridge and solid infill speeds vary greatly. The extra bridge layer results in reduced pillowing on top surfaces, as well as reduced separation of the external bridge layer from its surrounding perimeters.

It is generally recommended to set this to at least 'External bridge only', unless specific issues with the sliced model are found.

Options:
1. Disabled - does not generate second bridge layers. This is the default and is set for compatibility purposes
2. External bridge only - generates second bridge layers for external-facing bridges only. Please note that small bridges that are shorter or narrower than the set number of perimeters will be skipped as they would not benefit from a second bridge layer. If generated, the second bridge layer will be extruded parallel to the first bridge layer to reinforce the bridge strength
3. Internal bridge only - generates second bridge layers for internal bridges over sparse infill only. Please note that the internal bridges count towards the top shell layer count of your model. The second internal bridge layer will be extruded as close to perpendicular to the first as possible. If multiple regions in the same island, with varying bridge angles are present, the last region of that island will be selected as the angle reference
4. Apply to all - generates second bridge layers for both internal and external-facing bridges

enable_overhang_bridge_fan.label: Force cooling for overhangs and bridges
enable_overhang_bridge_fan.tooltip: Enable this option to allow adjustment of the part cooling fan speed for specifically for overhangs, internal and external bridges. Setting the fan speed specifically for these features can improve overall print quality and reduce warping.

enable_overhang_speed.label: Slow down for overhang
enable_overhang_speed.tooltip: Enable this option to slow printing down for different overhang degree.

enable_power_loss_recovery.label: Power Loss Recovery
enable_power_loss_recovery.tooltip: Choose how to control power loss recovery. When set to Printer configuration, the slicer will not emit power loss recovery G-code and will leave the printer's configuration unchanged. Applicable to Bambu Lab or Marlin 2 firmware based printers.

enable_pressure_advance.label: Enable pressure advance
enable_pressure_advance.tooltip: Enable pressure advance, auto calibration result will be overwritten once enabled.

enable_prime_tower.label: Enable
enable_prime_tower.tooltip: The wiping tower can be used to clean up the residue on the nozzle and stabilize the chamber pressure inside the nozzle, in order to avoid appearance defects when printing objects.

enable_timelapse.label: Enable timelapse for print
enable_timelapse.tooltip: If enabled, this slicing will be considered using timelapse.

enforce_support_layers.label: Enforce support for the first
enforce_support_layers.full_label: Enforce support for the first n layers
enforce_support_layers.tooltip: Generate support material for the specified number of layers counting from bottom, regardless of whether normal support material is enabled or not and regardless of any angle threshold. This is useful for getting more adhesion of objects having a very thin or poor footprint on the build plate.

eng_plate_temp.label: Other layers
eng_plate_temp.tooltip: Bed temperature for layers except the initial one. A value of 0 means the filament does not support printing on the Engineering Plate.

eng_plate_temp_initial_layer.label: Initial layer
eng_plate_temp_initial_layer.tooltip: Bed temperature of the initial layer. A value of 0 means the filament does not support printing on the Engineering Plate.

ensure_on_bed.label: Ensure on bed
ensure_on_bed.tooltip: Lift the object above the bed when it is partially below. Disabled by default.

ensure_vertical_shell_thickness.label: Ensure vertical shell thickness
ensure_vertical_shell_thickness.tooltip:
Add solid infill near sloping surfaces to guarantee the vertical shell thickness (top+bottom solid layers)
None: No solid infill will be added anywhere. Caution: Use this option carefully if your model has sloped surfaces
Critical Only: Avoid adding solid infill for walls
Moderate: Add solid infill for heavily sloping surfaces only
All: Add solid infill for all suitable sloping surfaces
Default value is All.

exclude_object.label: Exclude objects
exclude_object.tooltip: Enable this option to add EXCLUDE OBJECT command in G-code.

export_gcode.label: Export G-code
export_gcode.tooltip: Slice the model and export toolpaths as G-code.

export_sla.label: Export SLA
export_sla.tooltip: Slice the model and export SLA printing layers as PNG.

export_slicedata.label: Export slicing data
export_slicedata.tooltip: Export slicing data to a folder.

export_stl.label: Export STL
export_stl.tooltip: Export the objects as single STL.

export_stls.label: Export multiple STLs
export_stls.tooltip: Export the objects as multiple STLs to directory.

export_svg.label: Export SVG
export_svg.tooltip: Slice the model and export solid slices as SVG.

extra_loading_move.label: Extra loading distance
extra_loading_move.tooltip: When set to zero, the distance the filament is moved from parking position during load is exactly the same as it was moved back during unload. When positive, it is loaded further, if negative, the loading move is shorter than unloading.

extra_perimeters_on_overhangs.label: Extra perimeters on overhangs
extra_perimeters_on_overhangs.tooltip: Create additional perimeter paths over steep overhangs and areas where bridges cannot be anchored.

extra_solid_infills.label: Insert solid layers
extra_solid_infills.tooltip: Insert solid infill at specific layers. Use N to insert every Nth layer, N#K to insert K consecutive solid layers every N layers (K is optional, e.g. '5#' equals '5#1'), or a comma-separated list (e.g. 1,7,9) to insert at explicit layers. Layers are 1-based.

extruded_volume.label: Volume per extruder
extruded_volume.tooltip: Total filament volume extruded per extruder during the entire print.

extruded_volume_total.label: Total volume
extruded_volume_total.tooltip: Total volume of filament used during the entire print.

extruded_weight.label: Weight per extruder
extruded_weight.tooltip: Weight per extruder extruded during the entire print. Calculated from filament_density value in Filament Settings.

extruded_weight_total.label: Total weight
extruded_weight_total.tooltip: Total weight of the print. Calculated from filament_density value in Filament Settings.

extruder.label: Extruder
extruder.tooltip: The extruder to use (unless more specific extruder settings are specified). This value overrides perimeter and infill extruders, but not the support extruders.

extruder_clearance_height_to_lid.label: Height to lid
extruder_clearance_height_to_lid.tooltip: Distance of the nozzle tip to the lid. Used for collision avoidance in by-object printing.

extruder_clearance_height_to_rod.label: Height to rod
extruder_clearance_height_to_rod.tooltip: Distance of the nozzle tip to the lower rod. Used for collision avoidance in by-object printing.

extruder_clearance_radius.label: Radius
extruder_clearance_radius.tooltip: Clearance radius around extruder. Used for collision avoidance in by-object printing.

extruder_colour.label: Extruder Color
extruder_colour.tooltip: Only used as a visual help on UI.

extruder_offset.label: Extruder offset
extruder_offset.tooltip: If your firmware doesn't handle the extruder displacement you need the G-code to take it into account. This option lets you specify the displacement of each extruder with respect to the first one. It expects positive coordinates (they will be subtracted from the XY coordinate).

extruder_printable_height.label: Extruder printable height
extruder_printable_height.tooltip: Maximum printable height of this extruder which is limited by mechanism of printer.

extrusion_rate_smoothing_external_perime.label: Apply only on external features
extrusion_rate_smoothing_external_perime.tooltip: Applies extrusion rate smoothing only on external perimeters and overhangs. This can help reduce artefacts due to sharp speed transitions on externally visible overhangs without impacting the print speed of features that will not be visible to the user.

fan_cooling_layer_time.label: Layer time
fan_cooling_layer_time.tooltip: Part cooling fan will be enabled for layers of which estimated time is shorter than this value. Fan speed is interpolated between the minimum and maximum fan speeds according to layer printing time.

fan_kickstart.label: Fan kick-start time
fan_kickstart.tooltip:
Emit a max fan speed command for this amount of seconds before reducing to target speed to kick-start the cooling fan.
This is useful for fans where a low PWM/power may be insufficient to get the fan started spinning from a stop, or to get the fan up to speed faster.
Set to 0 to deactivate.

fan_max_speed.label: Fan speed
fan_max_speed.tooltip: Part cooling fan speed may be increased when auto cooling is enabled. This is the maximum speed for the part cooling fan.

fan_min_speed.label: Fan speed
fan_min_speed.tooltip: Minimum speed for part cooling fan.

fan_speedup_overhangs.label: Only overhangs
fan_speedup_overhangs.tooltip: Will only take into account the delay for the cooling of overhangs.

fan_speedup_time.label: Fan speed-up time
fan_speedup_time.tooltip:
Start the fan this number of seconds earlier than its target start time (you can use fractional seconds). It assumes infinite acceleration for this time estimation, and will only take into account G1 and G0 moves (arc fitting is unsupported).
It won't move fan commands from custom G-code (they act as a sort of 'barrier').
It won't move fan commands into the start G-code if the 'only custom start G-code' is activated.
Use 0 to deactivate.

filament_adaptive_volumetric_speed.label: Adaptive volumetric speed
filament_adaptive_volumetric_speed.tooltip: When enabled, the extrusion flow is limited by the smaller of the fitted value (calculated from line width and layer height) and the user-defined maximum flow. When disabled, only the user-defined maximum flow is applied.

filament_change_length.label: Filament ramming length
filament_change_length.tooltip: When changing the extruder, it is recommended to extrude a certain length of filament from the original extruder. This helps minimize nozzle oozing.

filament_colour.label: Color
filament_colour.tooltip: Only used as a visual help on UI.

filament_cooling_final_speed.label: Speed of the last cooling move
filament_cooling_final_speed.tooltip: Cooling moves are gradually accelerating towards this speed.

filament_cooling_initial_speed.label: Speed of the first cooling move
filament_cooling_initial_speed.tooltip: Cooling moves are gradually accelerating beginning at this speed.

filament_cooling_moves.label: Number of cooling moves
filament_cooling_moves.tooltip: Filament is cooled by being moved back and forth in the cooling tubes. Specify desired number of these moves.

filament_diameter.label: Diameter
filament_diameter.tooltip: Filament diameter is used to calculate extrusion in G-code, so it is important and should be accurate.

filament_end_gcode.label: End G-code
filament_end_gcode.tooltip: End G-code when finishing the printing of this filament.

filament_extruder_id.label: Filament extruder ID
filament_extruder_id.tooltip: The current extruder ID. The same as current_extruder.

filament_flow_ratio.label: Flow ratio
filament_flow_ratio.tooltip: The material may have volumetric change after switching between molten and crystalline states. This setting changes all extrusion flow of this filament in G-code proportionally. The recommended value range is between 0.95 and 1.05. You may be able to tune this value to get a nice flat surface if there is slight overflow or underflow.

filament_flush_temp.label: Flush temperature
filament_flush_temp.tooltip: Temperature when flushing filament. 0 indicates the upper bound of the recommended nozzle temperature range.

filament_flush_volumetric_speed.label: Flush volumetric speed
filament_flush_volumetric_speed.tooltip: Volumetric speed when flushing filament. 0 indicates the max volumetric speed.

filament_ironing_flow.label: Ironing flow
filament_ironing_flow.tooltip: Filament-specific override for ironing flow. This allows you to customize the ironing flow for each filament type. Too high value results in overextrusion on the surface.

filament_ironing_inset.label: Ironing inset
filament_ironing_inset.tooltip: Filament-specific override for ironing inset. This allows you to customize the distance to keep from the edges when ironing for each filament type.

filament_ironing_spacing.label: Ironing line spacing
filament_ironing_spacing.tooltip: Filament-specific override for ironing line spacing. This allows you to customize the spacing between ironing lines for each filament type.

filament_ironing_speed.label: Ironing speed
filament_ironing_speed.tooltip: Filament-specific override for ironing speed. This allows you to customize the print speed of ironing lines for each filament type.

filament_is_support.label: Support material
filament_is_support.tooltip: Support material is commonly used to print supports and support interfaces.

filament_loading_speed.label: Loading speed
filament_loading_speed.tooltip: Speed used for loading the filament on the wipe tower.

filament_loading_speed_start.label: Loading speed at the start
filament_loading_speed_start.tooltip: Speed used at the very beginning of loading phase.

filament_max_volumetric_speed.label: Max volumetric speed
filament_max_volumetric_speed.tooltip: This setting stands for how much volume of filament can be melted and extruded per second. Printing speed is limited by max volumetric speed, in case of too high and unreasonable speed setting. Can't be zero.

filament_minimal_purge_on_wipe_tower.label: Minimal purge on wipe tower
filament_minimal_purge_on_wipe_tower.tooltip: After a tool change, the exact position of the newly loaded filament inside the nozzle may not be known, and the filament pressure is likely not yet stable. Before purging the print head into an infill or a sacrificial object, Orca Slicer will always prime this amount of material into the wipe tower to produce successive infill or sacrificial object extrusions reliably.

filament_multitool_ramming.label: Enable ramming for multi-tool setups
filament_multitool_ramming.tooltip: Perform ramming when using multi-tool printer (i.e. when the 'Single Extruder Multimaterial' in Printer Settings is unchecked). When checked, a small amount of filament is rapidly extruded on the wipe tower just before the tool change. This option is only used when the wipe tower is enabled.

filament_multitool_ramming_flow.label: Multi-tool ramming flow
filament_multitool_ramming_flow.tooltip: Flow used for ramming the filament before the tool change.

filament_multitool_ramming_volume.label: Multi-tool ramming volume
filament_multitool_ramming_volume.tooltip: The volume to be rammed before the tool change.

filament_notes.label: Filament notes
filament_notes.tooltip: You can put your notes regarding the filament here.

filament_preset.label: Filament preset name
filament_preset.tooltip: Names of the filament presets used for slicing. The variable is a vector containing one name for each extruder.

filament_printable.label: Filament printable
filament_printable.tooltip: The filament is printable in extruder.

filament_ramming_parameters.label: Ramming parameters
filament_ramming_parameters.tooltip: This string is edited by RammingDialog and contains ramming specific parameters.

filament_shrink.label: Shrinkage (XY)
filament_shrink.tooltip:
Enter the shrinkage percentage that the filament will get after cooling (94% if you measure 94mm instead of 100mm). The part will be scaled in XY to compensate. For multi-material prints, ensure filament shrinkage matches across all used filaments
Be sure to allow enough space between objects, as this compensation is done after the checks.

filament_shrinkage_compensation_z.label: Shrinkage (Z)
filament_shrinkage_compensation_z.tooltip: Enter the shrinkage percentage that the filament will get after cooling (94% if you measure 94mm instead of 100mm). The part will be scaled in Z to compensate.

filament_soluble.label: Soluble material
filament_soluble.tooltip: Soluble material is commonly used to print supports and support interfaces.

filament_stamping_distance.label: Stamping distance measured from the center of the cooling tube
filament_stamping_distance.tooltip: If set to non-zero value, filament is moved toward the nozzle between the individual cooling moves ("stamping"). This option configures how long this movement should be before the filament is retracted again.

filament_start_gcode.label: Start G-code
filament_start_gcode.tooltip: Start G-code when starting the printing of this filament.

filament_toolchange_delay.label: Delay after unloading
filament_toolchange_delay.tooltip: Time to wait after the filament is unloaded. May help to get reliable tool changes with flexible materials that may need more time to shrink to original dimensions.

filament_unloading_speed.label: Unloading speed
filament_unloading_speed.tooltip: Speed used for unloading the filament on the wipe tower (does not affect initial part of unloading just after ramming).

filament_unloading_speed_start.label: Unloading speed at the start
filament_unloading_speed_start.tooltip: Speed used for unloading the tip of the filament immediately after ramming.

filament_vendor.label: Vendor
filament_vendor.tooltip: Vendor of filament. For show only.

file_start_gcode.label: File header G-code
file_start_gcode.tooltip: G-code written at the very top of the output file, before any other content. Useful for adding metadata that printer firmware reads from the first lines of the file (e.g. estimated print time, filament usage). Supports placeholders like {print_time_sec} and {used_filament_length}.

filename_format.label: Filename format
filename_format.tooltip: Users can define the project file name when exporting.

fill_multiline.label: Fill Multiline
fill_multiline.tooltip: Using multiple lines for the infill pattern, if supported by infill pattern.

filter_out_gap_fill.label: Filter out tiny gaps
filter_out_gap_fill.tooltip: Don't print gap fill with a length is smaller than the threshold specified (in mm). This setting applies to top, bottom and solid infill and, if using the classic perimeter generator, to wall gap fill.

first_layer_flow_ratio.label: First layer flow ratio
first_layer_flow_ratio.tooltip:
This factor affects the amount of material on the first layer for the extrusion path roles listed in this section.

For the first layer, the actual flow ratio for each path role (does not affect brims and skirts) will be multiplied by this value.

first_layer_print_convex_hull.label: First layer convex hull
first_layer_print_convex_hull.tooltip: Vector of points of the first layer convex hull. Each element has the following format:'[x, y]' (x and y are floating-point numbers in mm).

first_layer_print_max.label: Top-right corner of first layer bounding box

first_layer_print_min.label: Bottom-left corner of first layer bounding box

first_layer_print_size.label: Size of the first layer bounding box

flush_into_infill.label: Flush into objects' infill
flush_into_infill.tooltip: Purging after filament change will be done inside objects' infills. This may lower the amount of waste and decrease the print time. If the walls are printed with transparent filament, the mixed color infill will be seen outside. It will not take effect, unless the prime tower is enabled.

flush_into_objects.label: Flush into this object
flush_into_objects.tooltip: This object will be used to purge the nozzle after a filament change to save filament and decrease the print time. Colors of the objects will be mixed as a result. It will not take effect unless the prime tower is enabled.

flush_into_support.label: Flush into objects' support
flush_into_support.tooltip: Purging after filament change will be done inside objects' support. This may lower the amount of waste and decrease the print time. It will not take effect, unless the prime tower is enabled.

flush_multiplier.label: Flush multiplier
flush_multiplier.tooltip: The actual flushing volumes is equal to the flush multiplier multiplied by the flushing volumes in the table.

flush_volumes_matrix.label: Purging volumes
flush_volumes_matrix.tooltip: This matrix describes volumes (in cubic milimetres) required to purge the new filament on the wipe tower for any given pair of tools.

full_fan_speed_layer.label: Full fan speed at layer
full_fan_speed_layer.tooltip: Fan speed will be ramped up linearly from zero at layer "close_fan_the_first_x_layers" to maximum at layer "full_fan_speed_layer". "full_fan_speed_layer" will be ignored if lower than "close_fan_the_first_x_layers", in which case the fan will be running at maximum allowed speed at layer "close_fan_the_first_x_layers" + 1.

fuzzy_skin.label: Fuzzy Skin
fuzzy_skin.tooltip: Randomly jitter while printing the wall, so that the surface has a rough look. This setting controls the fuzzy position.

fuzzy_skin_first_layer.label: Apply fuzzy skin to first layer
fuzzy_skin_first_layer.tooltip: Whether to apply fuzzy skin on the first layer.

fuzzy_skin_mode.label: Fuzzy skin generator mode
fuzzy_skin_mode.tooltip:
Fuzzy skin generation mode. Works only with Arachne!
Displacement: Сlassic mode when the pattern is formed by shifting the nozzle sideways from the original path.
Extrusion: The mode when the pattern formed by the amount of extruded plastic. This is the fast and straight algorithm without unnecessary nozzle shake that gives a smooth pattern. But it is more useful for forming loose walls in the entire they array.
Combined: Joint mode [Displacement] + [Extrusion]. The appearance of the walls is similar to [Displacement] Mode, but it leaves no pores between the perimeters.

Attention! The [Extrusion] and [Combined] modes works only the fuzzy_skin_thickness parameter not more than the thickness of printed loop. At the same time, the width of the extrusion for a particular layer should also not be below a certain level. It is usually equal 15-25%% of a layer height. Therefore, the maximum fuzzy skin thickness with a perimeter width of 0.4 mm and a layer height of 0.2 mm will be 0.4-(0.2*0.25)=±0.35mm! If you enter a higher parameter than this, the error Flow::spacing() will displayed, and the model will not be sliced. You can choose this number until this error is repeated.

fuzzy_skin_noise_type.label: Fuzzy skin noise type
fuzzy_skin_noise_type.tooltip:
Noise type to use for fuzzy skin generation:
Classic: Classic uniform random noise.
Perlin: Perlin noise, which gives a more consistent texture.
Billow: Similar to perlin noise, but clumpier.
Ridged Multifractal: Ridged noise with sharp, jagged features. Creates marble-like textures.
Voronoi: Divides the surface into voronoi cells, and displaces each one by a random amount. Creates a patchwork texture.

fuzzy_skin_octaves.label: Fuzzy Skin Noise Octaves
fuzzy_skin_octaves.tooltip: The number of octaves of coherent noise to use. Higher values increase the detail of the noise, but also increase computation time.

fuzzy_skin_persistence.label: Fuzzy skin noise persistence
fuzzy_skin_persistence.tooltip: The decay rate for higher octaves of the coherent noise. Lower values will result in smoother noise.

fuzzy_skin_point_distance.label: Fuzzy skin point distance
fuzzy_skin_point_distance.tooltip: The average distance between the random points introduced on each line segment.

fuzzy_skin_scale.label: Fuzzy skin feature size
fuzzy_skin_scale.tooltip: The base size of the coherent noise features, in mm. Higher values will result in larger features.

fuzzy_skin_thickness.label: Fuzzy skin thickness
fuzzy_skin_thickness.tooltip: The width within which to jitter. It's advised to be below outer wall line width.

gap_fill_flow_ratio.label: Gap fill flow ratio
gap_fill_flow_ratio.tooltip:
This factor affects the amount of material for filling the gaps.

The actual gap filling flow used is calculated by multiplying this value by the filament flow ratio, and if set, the object's flow ratio.

gap_fill_target.label: Apply gap fill
gap_fill_target.tooltip:
Enables gap fill for the selected solid surfaces. The minimum gap length that will be filled can be controlled from the filter out tiny gaps option below.

Options:
1. Everywhere: Applies gap fill to top, bottom and internal solid surfaces for maximum strength
2. Top and Bottom surfaces: Applies gap fill to top and bottom surfaces only, balancing print speed, reducing potential over extrusion in the solid infill and making sure the top and bottom surfaces have no pinhole gaps
3. Nowhere: Disables gap fill for all solid infill areas

Note that if using the classic perimeter generator, gap fill may also be generated between perimeters, if a full width line cannot fit between them. That perimeter gap fill is not controlled by this setting.

If you would like all gap fill, including the classic perimeter generated one, removed, set the filter out tiny gaps value to a large number, like 999999.

However this is not advised, as gap fill between perimeters is contributing to the model's strength. For models where excessive gap fill is generated between perimeters, a better option would be to switch to the arachne wall generator and use this option to control whether the cosmetic top and bottom surface gap fill is generated.

gap_infill_speed.label: Gap infill
gap_infill_speed.tooltip: Speed of gap infill. Gap usually has irregular line width and should be printed more slowly.

gcode_add_line_number.label: Add line number
gcode_add_line_number.tooltip: Enable this to add line number(Nx) at the beginning of each G-code line.

gcode_comments.label: Verbose G-code
gcode_comments.tooltip: Enable this to get a commented G-code file, with each line explained by a descriptive text. If you print from SD card, the additional weight of the file could make your firmware slow down.

gcode_flavor.label: G-code flavor
gcode_flavor.tooltip: What kind of G-code the printer is compatible with.

gcode_label_objects.label: Label objects
gcode_label_objects.tooltip: Enable this to add comments into the G-code labeling print moves with what object they belong to, which is useful for the Octoprint CancelObject plugin. This settings is NOT compatible with Single Extruder Multi Material setup and Wipe into Object / Wipe into Infill.

gcodeviewer.label: G-code viewer
gcodeviewer.tooltip: Visualize an already sliced and saved G-code.

has_single_extruder_multi_material_primi.label: Has single extruder MM priming
has_single_extruder_multi_material_primi.tooltip: Are the extra multi-material priming regions used in this print?

has_wipe_tower.label: Has wipe tower
has_wipe_tower.tooltip: Whether or not wipe tower is being generated in the print.

help_fff.label: Help (FFF options)
help_fff.tooltip: Show the full list of print/G-code configuration options.

help_sla.label: Help (SLA options)
help_sla.tooltip: Show the full list of SLA print configuration options.

high_current_on_filament_swap.label: High extruder current on filament swap
high_current_on_filament_swap.tooltip: It may be beneficial to increase the extruder motor current during the filament exchange sequence to allow for rapid ramming feed rates and to overcome resistance when loading a filament with an ugly shaped tip.

hole_to_polyhole.label: Convert holes to polyholes
hole_to_polyhole.tooltip:
Search for almost-circular holes that span more than one layer and convert the geometry to polyholes. Use the nozzle size and the (biggest) diameter to compute the polyhole.
See http://hydraraptor.blogspot.com/2011/02/polyholes.html

hole_to_polyhole_threshold.label: Polyhole detection margin
hole_to_polyhole_threshold.tooltip:
Maximum defection of a point to the estimated radius of the circle.
As cylinders are often exported as triangles of varying size, points may not be on the circle circumference. This setting allows you some leeway to broaden the detection.
In mm or in % of the radius.

host_type.label: Host Type
host_type.tooltip: Orca Slicer can upload G-code files to a printer host. This field must contain the kind of the host.

hot_plate_temp.label: Other layers
hot_plate_temp.tooltip: Bed temperature for layers except the initial one. A value of 0 means the filament does not support printing on the High Temp Plate.

hot_plate_temp_initial_layer.label: Initial layer
hot_plate_temp_initial_layer.tooltip: Bed temperature of the initial layer. A value of 0 means the filament does not support printing on the High Temp Plate.

idle_temperature.label: Idle temperature
idle_temperature.tooltip: Nozzle temperature when the tool is currently not used in multi-tool setups. This is only used when 'Ooze prevention' is active in Print Settings. Set to 0 to disable.

ignore_nonexistent_config.label: Ignore non-existent config files
ignore_nonexistent_config.tooltip: Do not fail if a file supplied to --load does not exist.

independent_support_layer_height.label: Independent support layer height
independent_support_layer_height.tooltip: Support layer uses layer height independent with object layer. This is to support customizing Z-gap and save print time. This option will be invalid when the prime tower is enabled.

infill_anchor.label: Sparse infill anchor length
infill_anchor.tooltip:
Connect an infill line to an internal perimeter with a short segment of an additional perimeter. If expressed as percentage (example: 15%) it is calculated over infill extrusion width. Orca Slicer tries to connect two close infill lines to a short perimeter segment. If no such perimeter segment shorter than infill_anchor_max is found, the infill line is connected to a perimeter segment at just one side and the length of the perimeter segment taken is limited to this parameter, but no longer than anchor_length_max.
Set this parameter to zero to disable anchoring perimeters connected to a single infill line.

infill_anchor_max.label: Maximum length of the infill anchor
infill_anchor_max.tooltip:
Connect an infill line to an internal perimeter with a short segment of an additional perimeter. If expressed as percentage (example: 15%) it is calculated over infill extrusion width. Orca Slicer tries to connect two close infill lines to a short perimeter segment. If no such perimeter segment shorter than this parameter is found, the infill line is connected to a perimeter segment at just one side and the length of the perimeter segment taken is limited to infill_anchor, but no longer than this parameter.
If set to 0, the old algorithm for infill connection will be used, it should create the same result as with 1000 & 0.

infill_combination.label: Infill combination
infill_combination.tooltip: Automatically Combine sparse infill of several layers to print together to reduce time. Wall is still printed with original layer height.

infill_combination_max_layer_height.label: Infill combination - Max layer height
infill_combination_max_layer_height.tooltip:
Maximum layer height for the combined sparse infill.

Set it to 0 or 100% to use the nozzle diameter (for maximum reduction in print time) or a value of ~80% to maximize sparse infill strength.

The number of layers over which infill is combined is derived by dividing this value with the layer height and rounded down to the nearest decimal.

Use either absolute mm values (eg. 0.32mm for a 0.4mm nozzle) or % values (eg 80%). This value must not be larger than the nozzle diameter.

infill_direction.label: Sparse infill direction
infill_direction.tooltip: Angle for sparse infill pattern, which controls the start or main direction of line.

infill_lock_depth.label: Infill lock depth
infill_lock_depth.tooltip: The parameter sets the overlapping depth between the interior and skin.

infill_overhang_angle.label: Infill overhang angle
infill_overhang_angle.tooltip: The angle of the infill angled lines. 60° will result in a pure honeycomb.

infill_shift_step.label: Infill shift step
infill_shift_step.tooltip: This parameter adds a slight displacement to each layer of infill to create a cross texture.

infill_wall_overlap.label: Infill/Wall overlap
infill_wall_overlap.tooltip: Infill area is enlarged slightly to overlap with wall for better bonding. The percentage value is relative to line width of sparse infill. Set this value to ~10-15% to minimize potential over extrusion and accumulation of material resulting in rough top surfaces.

initial_extruder.label: Initial extruder
initial_extruder.tooltip: Zero-based index of the first extruder used in the print. Same as initial_tool.

initial_filament_type.label: Initial filament type
initial_filament_type.tooltip: String containing filament type of the first used extruder.

initial_layer_acceleration.label: Initial layer
initial_layer_acceleration.tooltip: Acceleration of initial layer. Using a lower value can improve build plate adhesion.

initial_layer_infill_speed.label: Initial layer infill
initial_layer_infill_speed.tooltip: Speed of solid infill part of initial layer.

initial_layer_line_width.label: Initial layer
initial_layer_line_width.tooltip: Line width of initial layer. If expressed as a %, it will be computed over the nozzle diameter.

initial_layer_min_bead_width.label: First layer minimum wall width
initial_layer_min_bead_width.tooltip: The minimum wall width that should be used for the first layer is recommended to be set to the same size as the nozzle. This adjustment is expected to enhance adhesion.

initial_layer_print_height.label: Initial layer height
initial_layer_print_height.tooltip: Height of initial layer. Making initial layer height to be thick slightly can improve build plate adhesion.

initial_layer_speed.label: Initial layer
initial_layer_speed.tooltip: Speed of initial layer except the solid infill part.

initial_tool.label: Initial tool
initial_tool.tooltip: Zero-based index of the first extruder used in the print. Same as initial_extruder.

inner_wall_flow_ratio.label: Inner wall flow ratio
inner_wall_flow_ratio.tooltip:
This factor affects the amount of material for inner walls.

The actual inner wall flow used is calculated by multiplying this value by the filament flow ratio, and if set, the object's flow ratio.

inner_wall_line_width.label: Inner wall
inner_wall_line_width.tooltip: Line width of inner wall. If expressed as a %, it will be computed over the nozzle diameter.

input_filename_base.label: Input filename without extension
input_filename_base.tooltip: Source filename of the first object, without extension.

interface_shells.label: Interface shells
interface_shells.tooltip: Force the generation of solid shells between adjacent materials/volumes. Useful for multi-extruder prints with translucent materials or manual soluble support material.

interlocking_beam.label: Use beam interlocking
interlocking_beam.tooltip: Generate interlocking beam structure at the locations where different filaments touch. This improves the adhesion between filaments, especially models printed in different materials.

interlocking_beam_layer_count.label: Interlocking beam layers
interlocking_beam_layer_count.tooltip: The height of the beams of the interlocking structure, measured in number of layers. Less layers is stronger, but more prone to defects.

interlocking_beam_width.label: Interlocking beam width
interlocking_beam_width.tooltip: The width of the interlocking structure beams.

interlocking_boundary_avoidance.label: Interlocking boundary avoidance
interlocking_boundary_avoidance.tooltip: The distance from the outside of a model where interlocking structures will not be generated, measured in cells.

interlocking_depth.label: Interlocking depth
interlocking_depth.tooltip: The distance from the boundary between filaments to generate interlocking structure, measured in cells. Too few cells will result in poor adhesion.

internal_bridge_angle.label: Internal bridge infill direction
internal_bridge_angle.tooltip:
Internal bridging angle override. If left to zero, the bridging angle will be calculated automatically. Otherwise the provided angle will be used for internal bridges. Use 180° for zero angle.

It is recommended to leave it at 0 unless there is a specific model need not to.

internal_bridge_density.label: Internal bridge density
internal_bridge_density.tooltip:
Controls the density (spacing) of internal bridge lines. 100% means solid bridge. Default is 100%.

Lower density internal bridges can help reduce top surface pillowing and improve internal bridge reliability as there is more space for air to circulate around the extruded bridge, improving its cooling speed.

This option works particularly well when combined with the second internal bridge over infill option, further improving internal bridging structure before solid infill is extruded.

internal_bridge_fan_speed.label: Internal bridges fan speed
internal_bridge_fan_speed.tooltip:
The part cooling fan speed used for all internal bridges. Set to -1 to use the overhang fan speed settings instead.

Reducing the internal bridges fan speed, compared to your regular fan speed, can help reduce part warping due to excessive cooling applied over a large surface for a prolonged period of time.

internal_bridge_flow.label: Internal bridge flow ratio
internal_bridge_flow.tooltip:
This value governs the thickness of the internal bridge layer. This is the first layer over sparse infill. Decrease this value slightly (for example 0.9) to improve surface quality over sparse infill.

The actual internal bridge flow used is calculated by multiplying this value with the bridge flow ratio, the filament flow ratio, and if set, the object's flow ratio.

internal_bridge_speed.label: Internal
internal_bridge_speed.tooltip: Speed of internal bridges. If the value is expressed as a percentage, it will be calculated based on the bridge_speed. Default value is 150%.

internal_solid_infill_acceleration.label: Internal solid infill
internal_solid_infill_acceleration.tooltip: Acceleration of internal solid infill. If the value is expressed as a percentage (e.g. 100%), it will be calculated based on the default acceleration.

internal_solid_infill_flow_ratio.label: Internal solid infill flow ratio
internal_solid_infill_flow_ratio.tooltip:
This factor affects the amount of material for internal solid infill.

The actual internal solid infill flow used is calculated by multiplying this value by the filament flow ratio, and if set, the object's flow ratio.

internal_solid_infill_line_width.label: Internal solid infill
internal_solid_infill_line_width.tooltip: Line width of internal solid infill. If expressed as a %, it will be computed over the nozzle diameter.

internal_solid_infill_pattern.label: Internal solid infill pattern
internal_solid_infill_pattern.tooltip: Line pattern of internal solid infill. if the detect narrow internal solid infill be enabled, the concentric pattern will be used for the small area.

internal_solid_infill_speed.label: Internal solid infill
internal_solid_infill_speed.tooltip: Speed of internal solid infill, not the top and bottom surface.

ironing_angle.label: Ironing angle offset
ironing_angle.tooltip: The angle of ironing lines offset from the top surface.

ironing_angle_fixed.label: Fixed ironing angle
ironing_angle_fixed.tooltip: Use a fixed absolute angle for ironing.

ironing_fan_speed.label: Ironing fan speed
ironing_fan_speed.tooltip:
This part cooling fan speed is applied when ironing. Setting this parameter to a lower than regular speed reduces possible nozzle clogging due to the low volumetric flow rate, making the interface smoother.
Set to -1 to disable it.

ironing_flow.label: Ironing flow
ironing_flow.tooltip: The amount of material to extrude during ironing. Relative to flow of normal layer height. Too high value results in overextrusion on the surface.

ironing_inset.label: Ironing inset
ironing_inset.tooltip: The distance to keep from the edges. A value of 0 sets this to half of the nozzle diameter.

ironing_pattern.label: Ironing Pattern
ironing_pattern.tooltip: The pattern that will be used when ironing.

ironing_spacing.label: Ironing line spacing
ironing_spacing.tooltip: The distance between the lines of ironing.

ironing_type.label: Ironing Type
ironing_type.tooltip: Ironing is using small flow to print on same height of surface again to make flat surface more smooth. This setting controls which layer being ironed

is_extruder_used.label: Is extruder used?
is_extruder_used.tooltip: Vector of booleans stating whether a given extruder is used in the print.

is_infill_first.label: Print infill first
is_infill_first.tooltip:
Order of wall/infill. When the tickbox is unchecked the walls are printed first, which works best in most cases.

Printing infill first may help with extreme overhangs as the walls have the neighbouring infill to adhere to. However, the infill will slightly push out the printed walls where it is attached to them, resulting in a worse external surface finish. It can also cause the infill to shine through the external surfaces of the part.

lateral_lattice_angle_1.label: Lateral lattice angle 1
lateral_lattice_angle_1.tooltip: The angle of the first set of Lateral lattice elements in the Z direction. Zero is vertical.

lateral_lattice_angle_2.label: Lateral lattice angle 2
lateral_lattice_angle_2.tooltip: The angle of the second set of Lateral lattice elements in the Z direction. Zero is vertical.

layer_change_gcode.label: Layer change G-code
layer_change_gcode.tooltip: This G-code is inserted at every layer change after the Z lift.

layer_height.label: Layer height
layer_height.tooltip: Slicing height for each layer. Smaller layer height means more accurate and more printing time.

layer_num.label: Layer number
layer_num.tooltip: Index of the current layer. One-based (i.e. first layer is number 1).

layer_z.label: Layer Z
layer_z.tooltip: Height of the current layer above the print bed, measured to the top of the layer.

line_width.label: Default
line_width.tooltip: Default line width if other line widths are set to 0. If expressed as a %, it will be computed over the nozzle diameter.

load.label: Load config file
load.tooltip: Load configuration from the specified file. It can be used more than once to load options from multiple files.

load_assemble_list.label: Load assemble list
load_assemble_list.tooltip: Load assemble object list from config file.

load_defaultfila.label: Load default filaments
load_defaultfila.tooltip: Load first filament as default for those not loaded.

load_filament_ids.label: Load filament IDs
load_filament_ids.tooltip: Load filament IDs for each object.

load_filaments.label: Load Filament Settings
load_filaments.tooltip: Load filament settings from the specified file list.

load_settings.label: Load General Settings
load_settings.tooltip: Load process/machine settings from the specified file.

load_slicedata.label: Load slicing data
load_slicedata.tooltip: Load cached slicing data from directory.

long_retractions_when_cut.label: Long retraction when cut (beta)
long_retractions_when_cut.tooltip: Experimental feature: Retracting and cutting off the filament at a longer distance during changes to minimize purge. While this reduces flush significantly, it may also raise the risk of nozzle clogs or other printing problems.

machine_end_gcode.label: End G-code
machine_end_gcode.tooltip: End G-code when finishing the entire print.

machine_load_filament_time.label: Filament load time
machine_load_filament_time.tooltip: Time to load new filament when switch filament. It's usually applicable for single-extruder multi-material machines. For tool changers or multi-tool machines, it's typically 0. For statistics only.

machine_pause_gcode.label: Pause G-code
machine_pause_gcode.tooltip: This G-code will be used as a code for the pause print. Users can insert pause G-code in the G-code viewer.

machine_start_gcode.label: Start G-code
machine_start_gcode.tooltip: Start G-code when starting the entire print.

machine_tool_change_time.label: Tool change time
machine_tool_change_time.tooltip: Time taken to switch tools. It's usually applicable for tool changers or multi-tool machines. For single-extruder multi-material machines, it's typically 0. For statistics only.

machine_unload_filament_time.label: Filament unload time
machine_unload_filament_time.tooltip: Time to unload old filament when switch filament. It's usually applicable for single-extruder multi-material machines. For tool changers or multi-tool machines, it's typically 0. For statistics only.

make_overhang_printable.label: Make overhangs printable
make_overhang_printable.tooltip: Modify the geometry to print overhangs without support material.

make_overhang_printable_angle.label: Make overhangs printable - Maximum angle
make_overhang_printable_angle.tooltip: Maximum angle of overhangs to allow after making more steep overhangs printable.90° will not change the model at all and allow any overhang, while 0 will replace all overhangs with conical material.

make_overhang_printable_hole_size.label: Make overhangs printable - Hole area
make_overhang_printable_hole_size.tooltip: Maximum area of a hole in the base of the model before it's filled by conical material. A value of 0 will fill all the holes in the model base.

manual_filament_change.label: Manual Filament Change
manual_filament_change.tooltip: Enable this option to omit the custom Change filament G-code only at the beginning of the print. The tool change command (e.g., T0) will be skipped throughout the entire print. This is useful for manual multi-material printing, where we use M600/PAUSE to trigger the manual filament change action.

max_bridge_length.label: Max bridge length
max_bridge_length.tooltip: Max length of bridges that don't need support. Set it to 0 if you want all bridges to be supported, and set it to a very large value if you don't want any bridges to be supported.

max_layer_height.label: Max
max_layer_height.tooltip: The highest printable layer height for the extruder. Used to limit the maximum layer height when enable adaptive layer height.

max_layer_z.label: Maximal layer Z
max_layer_z.tooltip: Height of the last layer above the print bed.

max_travel_detour_distance.label: Avoid crossing walls - Max detour length
max_travel_detour_distance.tooltip: Maximum detour distance for avoiding crossing wall. Don't detour if the detour distance is larger than this value. Detour length could be specified either as an absolute value or as percentage (for example 50%) of a direct travel path. Zero to disable.

max_volumetric_extrusion_rate_slope.label: Extrusion rate smoothing
max_volumetric_extrusion_rate_slope.tooltip:
This parameter smooths out sudden extrusion rate changes that happen when the printer transitions from printing a high flow (high speed/larger width) extrusion to a lower flow (lower speed/smaller width) extrusion and vice versa.

It defines the maximum rate by which the extruded volumetric flow in mm³/s can change over time. Higher values mean higher extrusion rate changes are allowed, resulting in faster speed transitions.

A value of 0 disables the feature.

For a high speed, high flow direct drive printer (like the Bambu lab or Voron) this value is usually not needed. However it can provide some marginal benefit in certain cases where feature speeds vary greatly. For example, when there are aggressive slowdowns due to overhangs. In these cases a high value of around 300-350 mm³/s² is recommended as this allows for just enough smoothing to assist pressure advance achieve a smoother flow transition.

For slower printers without pressure advance, the value should be set much lower. A value of 10-15 mm³/s² is a good starting point for direct drive extruders and 5-10 mm³/s² for Bowden style.

This feature is known as Pressure Equalizer in Prusa slicer.

Note: this parameter disables arc fitting.

max_volumetric_extrusion_rate_slope_segm.label: Smoothing segment length
max_volumetric_extrusion_rate_slope_segm.tooltip:
A lower value results in smoother extrusion rate transitions. However, this results in a significantly larger G-code file and more instructions for the printer to process.

Default value of 3 works well for most cases. If your printer is stuttering, increase this value to reduce the number of adjustments made.

Allowed values: 0.5-5

min_bead_width.label: Minimum wall width
min_bead_width.tooltip: Width of the wall that will replace thin features (according to the Minimum feature size) of the model. If the Minimum wall width is thinner than the thickness of the feature, the wall will become as thick as the feature itself. It's expressed as a percentage over nozzle diameter.

min_feature_size.label: Minimum feature size
min_feature_size.tooltip: Minimum thickness of thin features. Model features that are thinner than this value will not be printed, while features thicker than than this value will be widened to the minimum wall width. It's expressed as a percentage over nozzle diameter.

min_layer_height.label: Min
min_layer_height.tooltip: The lowest printable layer height for the extruder. Used to limit the minimum layer height when enable adaptive layer height.

min_length_factor.label: Minimum wall length
min_length_factor.tooltip:
Adjust this value to prevent short, unclosed walls from being printed, which could increase print time. Higher values remove more and longer walls.

NOTE: Bottom and top surfaces will not be affected by this value to prevent visual gaps on the outside of the model. Adjust 'One wall threshold' in the Advanced settings below to adjust the sensitivity of what is considered a top-surface. 'One wall threshold' is only visible if this setting is set above the default value of 0.5, or if single-wall top surfaces is enabled.

min_skirt_length.label: Skirt minimum extrusion length
min_skirt_length.tooltip:
Minimum filament extrusion length in mm when printing the skirt. Zero means this feature is disabled.

Using a non-zero value is useful if the printer is set up to print without a prime line.
Final number of loops is not taking into account while arranging or validating objects distance. Increase loop number in such case.

min_width_top_surface.label: One wall threshold
min_width_top_surface.tooltip:
If a top surface has to be printed and it's partially covered by another layer, it won't be considered at a top layer where its width is below this value. This can be useful to not let the 'one perimeter on top' trigger on surface that should be covered only by perimeters. This value can be a mm or a % of the perimeter extrusion width.
Warning: If enabled, artifacts can be created if you have some thin features on the next layer, like letters. Set this setting to 0 to remove these artifacts.

minimum_sparse_infill_area.label: Minimum sparse infill threshold
minimum_sparse_infill_area.tooltip: Sparse infill area which is smaller than threshold value is replaced by internal solid infill.

mmu_segmented_region_interlocking_depth.label: Interlocking depth of a segmented region
mmu_segmented_region_interlocking_depth.tooltip: Interlocking depth of a segmented region. It will be ignored if "mmu_segmented_region_max_width" is zero or if "mmu_segmented_region_interlocking_depth" is bigger than "mmu_segmented_region_max_width". Zero disables this feature.

mmu_segmented_region_max_width.label: Maximum width of a segmented region
mmu_segmented_region_max_width.tooltip: Maximum width of a segmented region. Zero disables this feature.

mstpp.label: mstpp
mstpp.tooltip: max slicing time per plate in seconds.

mtcpp.label: mtcpp
mtcpp.tooltip: max triangle count per plate for slicing.

no_check.label: No check
no_check.tooltip: Do not run any validity checks, such as G-code path conflicts check.

normal_print_time.label: Print time (normal mode)
normal_print_time.tooltip: Estimated print time when printed in normal mode (i.e. not in silent mode). Same as print_time.

notes.label: Configuration notes
notes.tooltip: You can put here your personal notes. This text will be added to the G-code header comments.

nozzle_hrc.label: Nozzle HRC
nozzle_hrc.tooltip: The nozzle's hardness. Zero means no checking for nozzle's hardness during slicing.

nozzle_temperature.label: Other layers
nozzle_temperature.tooltip: Nozzle temperature for layers after the initial one.

nozzle_temperature_initial_layer.label: Initial layer
nozzle_temperature_initial_layer.tooltip: Nozzle temperature for printing initial layer when using this filament.

nozzle_type.label: Nozzle type
nozzle_type.tooltip: The metallic material of nozzle. This determines the abrasive resistance of nozzle, and what kind of filament can be printed.

nozzle_volume.label: Nozzle volume
nozzle_volume.tooltip: Volume of nozzle between the cutter and the end of nozzle.

num_extruders.label: Number of extruders
num_extruders.tooltip: Total number of extruders, regardless of whether they are used in the current print.

num_instances.label: Number of instances
num_instances.tooltip: Total number of object instances in the print, summed over all objects.

num_objects.label: Number of objects
